keyFindings: House passed SAVE America Act (218-213) requiring documentary proof of citizenship to register and vote; Brennan Center estimates 21 million citizens lack readily available documentation (NPR/Brennan Center)

DOJ sued 24 states demanding unredacted voter registration files; courts in California, Oregon, Michigan, and Georgia dismissed lawsuits, but 12+ states signed MOUs allowing federal officials to request individual voter removals (CNN/Alaska Beacon)

Half of all top election officials in 11 Western states have left since 2020, taking 1,800+ years of combined experience; in 4 of 10 local offices, 2026 midterms will be run by people who have never administered a national election (Issue One/Votebeat)

ICE violated 96 court orders in 74 cases in Minnesota in January alone; federal judge held government attorney in civil contempt—first such finding in Trump's second term—imposing $500/day fines (NPR/CNN)

Washington Post analysis of 160+ lawsuits found administration defied roughly 35% of judicial rulings against it through outright refusal, misrepresentation, or procedural sidestepping—unprecedented in modern presidential history (Washington Post)

Trump attacked Supreme Court justices by name after 6-3 IEEPA tariffs ruling, calling them a 'disgrace,' and reimposed tariffs under different statute within hours; D.C. grand jury refused to indict six Democratic lawmakers in retributive prosecution attempt (NBC News/Washington Post)

CIA directed to retract 19 intelligence reports by Trump-appointed review board citing 'political bias'; topics included white violent extremism, pandemic impacts, and Middle East human rights; Sen. Warner called it 'politicization' of intelligence (NBC News/Washington Post)

Pentagon purged Chairman of Joint Chiefs, Chief of Naval Operations, Air Force Chief of Staff, DIA Director, and NSA Director; SecDef Hegseth ordered 20% reduction in four-star generals; five former defense secretaries condemned firings as 'reckless' (PBS/Just Security)

Trump threatened Insurrection Act against Minneapolis protesters with 1,500 active-duty troops on standby; CISA budget cut 17% ($491M), workforce reduced by one-third, all election security infrastructure dismantled ahead of 2026 midterms (NPR/Brennan Center/Cybersecurity Dive)

Schedule F finalized (effective March 8, 2026) reclassifying ~50,000 federal employees as at-will workers who can be fired without standard protections or Merit Systems Protection Board appeals (Federal News Network/Government Executive)

EPA revoked 2009 greenhouse gas endangerment finding—described as 'largest de-regulatory action in American history'—eliminating legal foundation for all federal emissions standards; multiple lawsuits expected (CNBC/NBC News)

SCOTUS provisionally allows firing of independent agency heads (NLRB, MSPB); definitive ruling in Trump v. Slaughter expected by July 2026; executive order total reaches 243 plus 57 memoranda and 129 proclamations (NBC News/Ballotpedia)

Supreme Court struck down IEEPA tariffs 6-3 in Learning Resources v. Trump, ruling IEEPA does not authorize tariffs; $133-179 billion collected under IEEPA authority with refund obligations unresolved (Holland & Knight/Penn Wharton)

Administration pivoted within hours to Section 122 tariffs at 15% globally, but statute has hard 150-day limit (expires July 24, 2026) and requires Congressional authorization for extension; legal experts question whether balance-of-payments precondition is met (CNBC/Yale Budget Lab)

Section 232 and 301 tariffs remain active; China retaliated with 15% tariffs on coal/LNG, export controls on tungsten, and added US companies to Unreliable Entity List; bilateral deals progressing with India and Argentina (Asia Times/CFR)

SpaceX received $714M in FY2026 Space Force contracts while DOGE cuts targeted other agencies but left Musk's companies untouched; Musk avoids public financial disclosure as Special Government Employee; his companies hold $38B+ in cumulative government contracts (Newsweek/Scripps News)

White House ballroom donors ($279B in contracts) shaped administration's AI infrastructure plan from which they directly benefit; 16 of 24 donors hold federal contracts including Palantir, Microsoft, Amazon, and Google (Washington Post/OpenSecrets)

DOGE claims 13,440 contract terminations totaling $61B but independent analysis estimates actual impact at ~$20B; Congress rejected most proposed spending cuts, with only 1 of 30 targeted programs eliminated (CBS News/Washington Times)

DOJ served grand jury subpoenas on Fed Chair Powell regarding headquarters renovation—first criminal investigation of Fed leadership in 113-year history; Powell stated threat of charges is 'a consequence of setting interest rates based on our best assessment' rather than presidential preferences (CNN/CNBC)
Two government shutdowns in Jan-Feb 2026; DHS suspended TSA PreCheck and Global Entry as of Feb 22; TSA employees facing missed paychecks in mid-March raising prospect of walkouts (NPR/Wikipedia)

DOGE mass workforce cuts (271,000 employees) estimated to cost taxpayers $135B this fiscal year through paid leave, re-hiring, and lost productivity; IRS alone projects $8.5B net revenue loss from 22,000 employee departures, with 10-year losses of $198B (CBS News/Cato Institute)

Don Lemon arrested by federal agents and charged with federal civil rights crimes for covering Minnesota church protest; independent journalist Georgia Fort also arrested; DOJ had twice failed to obtain warrants from a judge who found 'no evidence' of criminal behavior (PBS News/U.S. Press Freedom Tracker)

FBI conducted pre-dawn raid on Washington Post reporter Hannah Natanson's home, seizing all electronic devices; judge excoriated DOJ for failing to inform him of Privacy Protection Act shielding journalists from such searches (Washington Post/CNN)

Corporation for Public Broadcasting dissolved after Congress stripped $1.1B in funding; stations nationwide cutting staff and programming; FCC weaponizing 'equal time' rules—CBS preemptively censored a Colbert interview with a Democratic candidate (NBC News/Fortune)

Federal agents killed two U.S. citizens in Minneapolis during immigration enforcement—Renee Good shot in her car and Alex Pretti shot 10 times while on the ground after being pepper-sprayed; DHS admitted agents 'appear to have lied under oath' about a separate shooting incident (NPR/ProPublica)

Minneapolis killings triggered historic general strike (Jan 23) with 700+ businesses shuttering; protests spread to 300+ cities nationwide (Jan 30); union leaders organizing May Day national strike (Democracy Now!/The Intercept)

457 federal judges targeted with credible threats in 2025—150% increase from 2019; at least 33 pardoned January 6 defendants rearrested for new crimes including six charged with child sex crimes and five with illegal weapons possession (CBS News/19th News)

322,000+ federal employees departed government since Jan 2025—largest workforce reduction in U.S. history; three-month Congressional layoff moratorium expired week of Feb 23, reopening door for additional RIFs (Government Executive/Federal News Network)

Schedule F final rule published Feb 2026 (effective March 8) reclassifying ~50,000 employees as at-will; over 75% of inspector general positions now vacant—up from 30% at start of second term—effectively eliminating independent oversight (Government Executive/CBS News)

8,000+ government web pages and 3,000 datasets removed from public access—largest deletion of government information in internet history; agencies including EPA, NOAA, NASA affected; Internet Archive director called it unprecedented (Marketplace/Axios)
